results.name: 0 if n-th prime is even, 1 if n-th prime is == 1 mod 4, and -1 if n-th prime is == 3 mod 4.
comment: Also, sin(prime(n)*Pi/2), where prime(n) = A000040(n), Pi=3.1415... (original definition).
Also imaginary part of primes mapped as defined in A076340, A076341: a(n) = A076341(A000040(n)), real part = A076342.
Legendre symbol (-1/prime(n)) for n > 1. - _T. D. Noe_, Nov 05 2003

For n>1, let p = prime(n) and m = (p-1)/2. Then c(m) - a(n) = 0 mod p, where c(m) = (2*m)!/(m!)^2 = A000984(m) is the central binomial coefficient [Proof: By definition, c(m)*(m!)^2 - (p-1)! = 0 and therefore c(m)*(m!)^2*(-1)^(m+1) - (p-1)!*(-1)^(m+1) = 0. Now apply Wilson's theorem, (p-1)! = 1 mod p, and its corollary, (m!)^2 = (-1)^(m+1) mod p, and finally use the formula by T. D. Noe listed below to replace (-1)^m by a(n).]. Similarly, C_m - 2*a(n) = 0 mod p, with C_m = A000108(m) being the m-th Catalan number [Proof: By definition, C_m*(p+1)*(m!)^2 - 2*(p-1)! = 0. The result follows proceeding as in the first proof.]. - _Stanislav Sykora_, Aug 11 2014
